Colin, that sounds like a promising start!  How many generations did
you run, what was your pop size, and did you get a chance to look at
the winning structure at all?  One thing that's also always useful to
check is that the number of species is reasonable over the run...huge
explosions of species, or lack of species, can indicate a problem.

Can you give a little more info on what you mean by "amalgamate
matching innovations per generation?"  I thought you meant refreshing
the recorded list of innovation numbers each generation, but then when
you ask whether I do this in the initial population as well, I'm not
sure what you mean?  In the initial population, every individual has
the same exact (minimal) structure, and hence every individual has the
same exact innovation numbers on each matching link.  So hopefully I
can answer your question better after I get a better understanding of
what you mean.

As far as elitism, keep in mind each species should have its best
member copied (as opposed to only the best in the population).  It
definitely should make a positive difference in performance, assuming
your species are not too small.  Also, you should probably be using a
dynamic speciation threshold if you are running more than 50
generations or so.  If you don't know how to do this, let me know.

On more question, is your prey domain animated so you can watch the
solutions?

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> As some of you will be aware I have been working on a C#
implementation 
> of NEAT (which I have deciced to name SharpNEAT). The final pieces
of 
> the core code were put in place today and although I really should
unit 
> test some of the latest code I couldn't resist the temptation to
fire it 
> up using a prey capture domain I had coded for a previous EANN
project.
> 
> Results?  so far so good - the prey capture domain is based on the
one 
> described in the 1996 paper "Incremental Evolution of Complex
General 
> Behavior" (Faustino Gomez, Risto Miikkulainen). Basically the task 
> difficulty can be increased by giving the prey a varying number of
head 
> starts (0 to 4) and then gradually increasing it's speed from 0.0 to
1.0 
> moves per domain time-slice.
> 
> The goal task is to solve 4, 1.0   (4 initial moves and a speed of
1.0). 
> Previously the most difficult task I was able to solve was 4, 0.3.  
> Things kind of ground to a halt after that. Using the new NEAT 
> implementation is so far giving better results - so far it has
'solved' 
> 4, 0.8.  The best network currently passes 75/100 tests on 4, 1.0. 
Not 
> a bad start.
> 
> I've just added in code to amalgamate matching innovations per 
> generation (as Ken mentions in the competitive coevolution paper).
Ken, 
> I wonder - do you amalgamate matching structures in your initial 
> populations too? it would make sense to, currently I don't.
> 
> One remaining significant thing I'm not doing is elitist selection
- my 
> evolution algorithm is currently a pure roulette wheel selection.
So 
> this will likely improve things when I change it.
> 
> So there you go. I will spend some time unit testing / tweaking and 
> hopefully I will have the 4, 1.0 test solved this week and I can
move 
> onto some visualisation and/or XML stuff maybe.
> 
> Colin.
